title: The Indian Railways Braking System
summary: How friction, momentum, and force engineering stop a 5000-tonne train safely.
content:
Case Study: Indian Railways Braking System

Indian Railways is one of the largest rail networks in the world, carrying millions of passengers daily. Stopping these massive trains safely is a masterclass in applied Newton's Laws.

The Challenge

A fully loaded express train can weigh over 5,000 tonnes and travel at 130 km/h. Its kinetic energy is enormous: KE = ½mv² ≈ 3.3 × 10⁹ J. This energy must be safely dissipated to stop the train.

How Brakes Work

Braking systems press brake pads against wheels. Friction converts kinetic energy to heat. The braking force must be carefully calculated: too much causes wheels to lock (skidding), too little means the train won't stop in time.

Impulse-Momentum Theorem

Braking force × braking time = change in momentum. To stop in 1 km, engineers calculate the minimum braking force needed. Modern trains use disc brakes and regenerative braking (which recovers energy as electricity).

Safety Systems

Anti-lock Braking Systems (ABS) prevent wheel lock-up. The Train Protection Warning System (TPWS) automatically applies brakes if the driver misses a signal. These are all based on physics!
